items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026. This information is correct as of 3:30pm on Tuesday 27 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 13cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 9cm of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 . 25mm of rain has been recorded on Tuesday. 
From 13:00 27/01/2026 flooding could begin to approach riverside properties on Forewood Lane and near Crowhurst Recreation Ground. From 16:00 on 27/01/2026, Bexhill Road Recreation Ground, and gardens that back onto the rec (or near the Combe Haven) could be affected. Rain is forecast to stop by 13:00 27/01/2026, with only isolated showers Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 18:00 on 27/01/2026, in Crowhurst, but not until 08:00 on 28/01/2026 in Bulverhythe. items.message: The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.91m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 8.25m and rising. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once river spillways stop running. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area. Therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 27 January 2026, around the Oxford area. Heavy and persistent rainfall will continue this morning, clearing by early afternoon leaving a predominantly dry afternoon and night. Tomorrow is expected to be predominantly dry. River levels are expected to rise in response to heavy rainfall over the coming days.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 pm on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour at Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding tomorrow. 
Flooding is expected on 28 January 2026 .   
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites. River levels continue to rise on the Lower Dorset Stour. Further heavy showers are forecast over the next few days that will keep levels high. Flooding is expected to affect Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites, Iford Bridge Home Park, and surrounding properties, from tomorrow late morning, Wednesday 28 January 2026. 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities and will continue to monitor the situation. 
Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so and activate any flood protection products you may have. 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour from Sturminster Marshall to Christchurch

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 and 28 January 2026.   
Areas most at risk include farms at Sturminster Marshall, Cowgrove, Shops in Wimborne, Mill Street in Corfe Mullen, Bridge House Hotel in Ferndown, Brecon Close, Ringwood Road, Throop Road in Bournemouth, Barrack Road and Willow Way in Christchurch. Levels along the Lower Dorset Stour are continuing to rise steadily following recent rainfall. Flooding is expected to affect Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites, Iford Bridge Home Park, and surrounding properties, tomorrow afternoon, Wednesday 28 January 2026. 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities and continue to monitor the situation. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. 
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels across West Somerset remain high on Tuesday 27th January, particularly on the Washford River. Flooding is possible as a result. Areas most at risk include the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and their tributaries, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1PM on 28/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 5:30am to 9:00am on 27/1/26. 
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Poole Harbour of 1.34 mAODN at 07:00AM on 26 January 2026, with Southerly force 6 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.) 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.80m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.81m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and temporary pumps are also being deployed to Northmoor. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. The main areas of concern are Taddiport (properties around Taddiport Bridge, Sewage Treatment Works and B3227) and Weare Giffard (riverside properties and roads). This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 , as a lot of rain fell in Storm Chandra (36mm). 
Flooding is affecting low-lying land and the road at Rectory Road, nearest the railway line at West Dean as well as properties in West Dean. River levels and flood risk will remain high throughout most of the evening. The river levels should begin to fall by tomorrow morning (28/01/2026). Only a small amount of rain is forecast over the next 48 hours, giving the river a chance to recover. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and we continue to monitor the forecast. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and we recommend moving cars parked close to the river in West Dean. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 , as a lot of rain (35mm) fell on Tuesday. 
Flooding will affect properties nearest the river in Chandlers Ford through Hiltingbury, Cuckoo Bushes, Common Road, Valley Road, Merrieleas Drive, and Mead Road. In Eastleigh, the river may flood Fleming Park, gardens and impact property at Kingfisher Road, Pennine Way, Skipton Road, Magpie Lane, Brookside Way, Stoneham Lane and Stoneham Way. Rain has started to clear the area. Showers are forecast this evening (27/01/2026). The river level has now peaked and will decrease slowly over the next 24 hours. Flooding impacts are expected to continue throughout much of today (27/01/2026). 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions and report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding.

Flooding is affecting roads and watersplash areas (Brookley Road) and riverside property at Martin's Road and Balmer Lawn. Property flooding could also occur at Meerut Road, Fathersfield and Butts Lawn. Property and outbuildings at Boldre and Pilley Hill may also experience impacts. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 8 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. During high water, the incoming tide will prevent the river from flowing out to sea. High tide is at 17:18 and at 18:48. River levels and flood risk will remain high for the remainder of the day.

We are closing flood gates and we will be on site to operate Lymington Toll Bridge flood gate if required.

Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst.

This message will be updated by 20:00 28/01/2026.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.73m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.76m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and temporary pumps are also being deployed to Northmoor. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday with blustery showers, heavy at times.  We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 as a lot of rain fell in Storm Chandra (35mm). 
Impacts are expected from 16:30 and during high tide. The next high tide will be at 17:45 at a height of 4.58mCD. Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Some water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Parts of Riverside Park will also be flooded. As the river continues to respond to this mornings rain, levels could also become very high at Gaters Mill. Showers are forecast to continue until today but the worst of the rain should have cleared. Flood risk should reduce for the following tide at 06:15 28/101/2026. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have , including defences around the White Swan pub. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Activate any flood protection products you may have near Lindfield Bridge and Dean's Water Mill. 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Flooding could affect fields at Titchfield Hill with high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and the Tanneries Industrial Estate. While groundwater and river levels are currently high, any intense rainfall events are now likely to cause surface water flooding in Titchfield High Street. Showers are forecast to continue this morning. River levels and flood risk are likely to remain elevated into next week. We will issue a Flood Warning if we expect property flooding to occur. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and managing water levels in the Titchfield Canal. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Particularly properties close to the river in Titchfield. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently high at our Draycot borehole in the Upper Og Valley. We expect levels to rise over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

The forecast is for heavy rain on Tuesday 27 January clearing into a predominantly dry Wednesday 28 January. Showers are then expected into the end of the week. Depending on the rainfall received, we may see localised impacts groundwater impacts. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are closely monitoring rainfall and groundwater levels.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cerne Valley
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 27 January 2026. 
Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Charminster and nearby areas. The groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has risen to 172.03m, and is expected to rise further due to recent rainfall. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Flooding will affect Privett Road and footpaths at Alver Country Park, especially near to Apple Dumpling Bridge. River levels and flood risk have reduced following the clearance of the outfall on Monday. However, Storm Chandra's rain combined with strong winds and high waves, means flows through the outfall could become impeded by shingle, increasing flood risk again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our operations staff will clear the outfall again if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 13:00 on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Pimperne Brook
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 24 January 2026 onwards. 
The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is rising in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so as more rain is forecast. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk . 
This message will be updated by 11:41AM on 31 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.75m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.77m. Cutts Road and New Road are closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is also closed. For road closure information please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and are deploying temporary pumps to Northmoor pumping station. The River Tone level is currently too high for pumping at Currymoor. We will commence pumping at Currymoor and operate the Parrett Relief Channel once river levels allow. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday with blustery showers, heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 6PM on 27/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from the 25th January 2026. 
Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Piddletrentide, Plush, Piddlehinton, Puddletown, Tolpuddle and Affpuddle. The groundwater level at the Doles Ash borehole has risen to 122m, and is expected to rise further over the next few days. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Parrett (lower) at Langport Westover Trading Estate
items.message: The level in the Westover Drain continues to rise and flooding is expected on Tuesday 27 January 2026. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Parrett, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. Areas most at risk include Cheapside, Whatley Mews, Parrett Close, Bow Street, Moor Park and Westover Trading Estate. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday with blustery showers, heavy at times. Rivers, and levels in the moors, are rising in response to last nights rain. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking flood banks and spillways. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 6PM on 27/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Wednesday, 28/01/2026, following a wet January 2026. 
Flooding could affect the electricity sub station in Rectory Lane, Meonstoke. The Winterbourne will begin to flow across Rectory Lane and behind the Buck's Head Pub. Tomorrow (27/01/2026), Storm Chandra will pass through the south of England, bringing up to 50mm of rain to Hampshire. A combination of high river flows and groundwater may affect a couple of cellars of properties on West Meon High Street and Lynch Lane. Lighter rain is forecast from Wednesday (28/01/2026) to Friday (30/01/2026). Groundwater levels at the borehole at Pound Lane, Meonstoke will continue rising through this week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Friday 30/01/2026, following a wet January 2026. 
Flooding could affect cellars of a small number of properties in Lower West Street from Friday 30/01/2026. From early next week, it is possible that an increased number of properties on West Street and East Street could experience cellar flooding impacts. Tomorrow (27/01/2026), Storm Chandra will pass through the south of England, bringing up to 50mm of rain to Hampshire. Lighter rain is forecast from Wednesday (28/01/2026) to Friday (30/01/2026). Groundwater levels at the borehole at Whitedale Farm are expected to continue rising for at least 7 days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: West Dean to Dunbridge on the River Dun
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 , as a lot of rain fell in Storm Chandra (36mm).   
Flooding is affecting property at West Dean, near the railway line at the bottom of Rectory Hill. River levels and flood risk will remain high throughout most of the evening. The river levels should begin to fall by early tomorrow morning (28/01/2026). Only a small amount of rain is forecast over the next 48 hours, giving the river a chance to recover. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and keeping the River Dun free of reported blockages. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have and move cars parked at Rectory Hill. 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The groundwater level at The Terraces borehole has risen to 117.34m, and is expected to rise due to rainfall. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Brain through Braintree, to and including Witham
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026  
Areas most at risk are properties at The Waterings, and St. Johns Avenue in Braintree, and Bridge Street and Guithavon Valley in Witham. It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
High water levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026  
HEPS drain level is currently 8.33m. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Pumping will begin at HEPS as soon as river levels allow. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message:
High water levels are expected to cause flooding tomorrow morning. 
Flooding is expected on 28 January 2026 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around Moorland including Horlake, Saltmoor, Fordgate and Chadmead. Currymoor is still rising from last nights rainfall. Athelney spillway is still running and we are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmooor. Additional pumping capacity is being added. The forecast for Wednesday is for blustery showers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. 
This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
